lesson_subtitle: Identifying Common Factors and Common Multiples
lesson_description: In this lesson, students create rectangles with given areas and relate their dimensions to factors and common factors.‚Äã They use prime factorizations to determine the greatest common factor (GCF) and the least common multiple (LCM) of two numbers. Students examine the rows and the columns of an area model to identify multiples and the LCM.
learning_goals: I can determine the greatest common factor of two whole numbers less than or equal to 100.
I can determine the least common multiple of two whole numbers less than or equal to 12.
I can use the Distributive Property to rewrite the sum of two whole numbers with a common factor as a multiple of the sum of two whole numbers with no common factor.
essential_ideas: Prime factorization is a method to determine common factors and common multiples of two numbers.
The greatest common factor (GCF) of two numbers is the largest factor shared by the two numbers.
The least common multiple (LCM) of two numbers is the smallest nonzero multiple shared by the two numbers.
You can use the Commutative and Distributive Properties to generate equivalent expressions.
If two numbers a and b are relatively prime, then the GCF(a, b) = 1 and the LCM(a, b) = ab.
